comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: No Averill's at No. 36 in the 1901 census. A family of Purcells including a Labourer and a Confectioner www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003762111/ In fact it looks like there were three apartments in the house: Purcell, Coleman & Booker www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Dublin/Mountjoy...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Poor Mr Byrne had died by the time of the 1911 census and his children had adopted the Irish form of the surname www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai000067249/ I'd say this puts the photo after 1901 as they were still using the English form at that stage. The youngest daughter was a "Professor in French engaged in Research Work" by the time of the 1911 census

comment._content: I can't find any reference to an Averill in Dublin around that time. There is only one listed in the 1901 census and she is a visitor to a house in Harold's Cross. In Pettigrew & Oulton's Dublin Directory 1842 Dublin Directory No. 36 Sackville Street is listed as the Spadacini Hotel with a Jones Wood Gibson as proprietor

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] There's an old saying that we see what we want to see.  There's a sign over a pile of books in the window that I took to say "Mice - Men" and thought of John Steinbecks novel but that came out in 1937 so that was a wild goose.  The fact that those posters are so indistinct is frustrating as they would have been very helpful.  Having said that the lovely lady in her beautiful clothes and the group of boys in their best bib and tucker behind make for a fabulous shot.  I doubt that they are playing marbles, a group formed like that is far more likely to be playing conkers which might give you an approximate time of year?

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: some more clarification on the Byrne Clan; Byrne (variations: Byrnes, O'Byrne) is a surname derived from the Irish name Ó Broin, and is the seventh most common surname in Ireland today.[citation needed] In the Irish language, 'Ó Broin' means "descendant of Bran". The name has been traced back to the ancient Celtic chieftain, Bran mac Máelmórda, King of Leinster, deposed in 1018, (d. 1052), who belonged to the Uí Dúnlainge dynasty. He was descended from Cathair Mór, an earlier king of Leinster, who was, according to medieval Irish legend and historical tradition, also monarch of all Ireland around 200 AD. The clan's motto is the Latin phrase Certavi et vici, meaning "I have fought and conquered".[1][2][3][4] In pre-Norman times the O'Byrnes, then known as the Uí Fáeláin sept, inhabited the rich Kildare plains. With the progress of the Anglo-Norman conquest, they were compelled to migrate to the poorer lands and the mountainous country eastwards, later to be denominated as the county of Wicklow. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byrne

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
On Sept 12 1896  John Averill, confectioner, was cautioned at the Dublin Police Court for offences under she shop hours act. (Belfast Newsletter).

In October 1898 a John Averill was fined 5s for not displaying a notice of the Shop Hours Act. He was also charged for employing Isabella Foster for 75 hours a week, the limit being 74 hours, but this charge was withdrawn. But this John Averill's address was given as 3 Aungier(?) Street (Freeman's)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The photographer J.J. Clarke (a medical student - www.nli.ie/en/udlist/photographs-collections.aspx?article...) sounds like an interesting character. I wonder how "candid" these shots were? Did he use a 'detective camera' hidden in a parcel or a bag, like a fellow who did similar things around Sydney in the 1880s, Arthur K. Syer (see www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/sets/721576267310... and the blurb here - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=442936 . From the shadow it looks like he might be touching his hat to the lady, who looks away and licks her lips (body language expert required!), whilst surreptitiously shooting from the hip. Or am I just seeing what I want to see?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Lookie here! Phoenix Park Racecourse is a former horse racing venue in Ireland. It was located in Castleknock, Fingal on the northern edge of the Phoenix Park. The course was founded by J. H. H. Peard, and racing began there in 1902.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There was a meeting in the Phoenix Park in October 1902. Given the Duke of York stakes was on the 15th of October that year, I think that is the earliest date for this photo.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The furore over the Education Bill imperilled the Liberal Unionist wing of the government, with the prospect of Nonconformist voters switching allegiance to the Liberal Party. Chamberlain sought to stem the feared exodus by securing a major concession: local authorities would be given the discretion over the issue of rate aid to voluntary schools, yet even this was renounced before the guillotining of the Bill and its passage through Parliament in December 1902. I see an article in the Irish Times of the 14th October headlined THE EDUCATION BILL (page 6), and another on the 17th (on page 5), and more on the 22nd.

comment.author: 14302637@N08

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Pickwick Bicycle Club, 1902: May 16th to 19th.- Whitsun Tour in Ireland. Conducted by Serjeant Buzfuz (Mr. J.C. Percy, of Dublin). There is a very full description in the Irish Wheelman of the period of this tour. The weather was bad, and the occasion will doubtless be impressed upon memories of all those joining the tour, by the shocking catastrophe which happened to a boat full of tourists, and the boatman accompanying them, all being drowned, on the Killarney Lakes. Or, if not limited to Ireland alone: October 4th.- Inter-club run with London Scottish and Dartmouth Park Clubs to the Old Salisbury at Barnet. The weather was bad, and but few members went; an enjoyable evening was, however, spent.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Wikipedia again: The Irish People(Sept. 1899 - Nov. 1903 and 30 September 1905 – 27 March 1909) was a news paper published in cork by the MP William O'Brien. So: Phoenix Park: 1902 on Duke of York Stakes: mid-October Irish People: up to Nov 1903. I really fancy mid-October 1902.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: 1902 would fit with the fact that the Byrnes seem to have adopted the Irish form of the name after the 1901 census. I'd still love to know where all the Averills were in 1901 though. They seem to have disappeared from the country altogether.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Of no use in dating the picture but in estate-agentese a description of No 35 from Freeman's Feb 27 1892
SPLENDID BUSINESS PREMISES 35 SACKVILLE STREET, UPPER (Within one door of Great Britain street) Formerly occupied by Messrs Thomas Webb and Co. There is a spacious, handsome, well-lighted Shop, modern front, with large Wareroom behind. The drawing room floor consistes of a suite of showrooms, which could be divided into Offices or Commercial Chambers, if desired. The upper floors are at present connected with the upper portion of the corner house, and let to a desirable tenant at £26. The premises are held for ever, subject to £42 per annum. The situation is a first-class one for any respectable business.
Georege Webb & Co sold clothing Webbs address normally appears as 36 Sackville St (& 11 George St) up to this time, and in 1880 as 34,35 & 36. Arthur Webb sold boots & shoes at number 34 until 1892, when he announced he had closed the Sackville St shop and moved the stock to his shop in Westmoreland St. Incidentally, in 1889 in a list of business closing early one day, their address is given as 36 O'COnnnell ST.

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The Irish Times on Thursday October 30th 1902 reported that a conference had been proposed about land issues in Limerick by a Lord Dunraven. It also reported that several nationalist MPs had absented themselves from a debate about an education bill, but that a few had remained to discuss this 'important bill'. I can't recall if the Times mentioned the conference the day before but the bill had been slowly progressing through parliament for a week and the actions reported on the 30th were a surprise. Could we say its the 30th of October 1902 (give or take a day?)

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: Did some further research on this and the meeting I referred to above was the first of a series which would eventually culminate in the 1903 land act a few months later.
